bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to W.E. Safford, April 27, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] thanks Safford for his letter describing his theories on plant origins.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to W.E. Safford, April 27, 1923
div1.opener:
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
April 27, 1923.
Mr. W. E. Safford,
Economic Botanist,
Bureau of Plant Industry,
U. S. Department of Agriculture,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Mr. Safford:
div1.p:
Your letter and reprint just received and I am very much obliged
to you for both of them, especially for the discussion contained in the
letter.

I had not understood you to say that the banana was a New World
product, but simply that Cook was mistaken--in what way you did not say--
in his contention that it was brought in in pre-Columbian days.

I will be exceedingly glad to see the reprint of the paper you
read at Rio Janeiro when you have one.as I have always been interested
in “things that grow in the ground.”
